titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:30. I wrote a short Letter this Morning to Mr Maury, and brought up my Journal to this day. But I wasted much of my time in arranging papers, and was interrupted while correcting George’s translation from Cicero, which we did not afterwards resume— Mr Nathl: Amory and his wife paid us a morning visit— I took a walk of half an hour with George,
and we all dined at Dr: Nicholas’s— The company at dinner consisted of the Drs. eldest daughter and two eldest Sons, and several Ladies and Gentlemen of the neighbourhood— Mrs: Wims, the wife of a General of that name, with a Miss Blair— Mr: and Mrs Copland, Mr and Mrs Morrison, and Mr and Mrs Gray, and a Mr Von Harten a German— This Gentleman asked me, if I recollected having in the year 1809 met at sea, off the Orkney Islands a vessel called the Edward of New-York, then bound to the Elk. I had a distinct recollection of it— He said he was on board of that vessel— It is mentioned in my Journal of 13. September 1809. He has since been to America, and is married to an American Lady; a native of Fairfield in Connecticut. He has resided in this vicinity these two years— Our entertainment was the most elegant and sumptuous, of any that I have been at in England— After dinner the Ladies retired, and the Gentlemen sat upwards of an hour longer— On returning to the Parlour we found there Dr Nicholas’s three younger daughters— There were cards, and one whist party was made. Mrs Copland and the eldest Miss Nicholas played upon the Piano, and the Harp, and sung very well. Doctor Nicholas’s two Sons had been shooting Partridges, from four O’Clock this Morning— The Season for shooting commences this day. Mr Copland told me that he was going on a shooting party down in to Norfolk— It was between 11 and 12 O’Clock when we came home.

2. VI:15. I received this morning a note from Mr Grubb, saying that he had received from a Portuguese Gentleman, just arrived from the Brazils, a large packet of letters, too bulky to be sent by the Post-Office— There was a card also from the bearer, the Chevalier de Sodré, with a note from Mr Sumter to him, recommending the despatch to his care with extraordinary precautions— And he is to go to morrow morning for Paris— I concluded therefore to go in to London, and after calling at several Coachmakers to look for a Carriage without suiting my self, I paid visits to Mr & Mrs Amory, who were not at home, to Mr Del Real, and to the Chevalier de Sodre whom I found. He told me that he had been the Duke of Wellington’s Portuguese Secretary during all the war in the Peninsula, and had been to Brezil to solicit the appointment of Minister to Holland; but that Mr d’Araujo had contrived to place there, one of his own Protegés, Mr Brito. He spoke with great freedom and of the Court there, which he said was in a state of Siege between the Lisbonians and the Brazilians.— He spoke like a disapointed and discontented man, and told me that he intended to return here in about a month from Paris. I went to my Office, and found there the packet from Mr Sumter— It enclosed a Letter from him to me, several other papers, and a packet for the Comte de la Châtre, the French Ambassador, with particular directions to have it delivered to him. I took it myself to his house; but he was at his Country Seat, at Battersea. I left it with his private Secretary, with the injunction to have it delivered to him as soon as possible— I returned home to dinner. Dr Bollmann and Mr M’Murtrie dined with us— Only two persons out of thirteen whom we had invited. John and Charles were also at home to dinner; but returned to School, at eight in the Evening. Mrs Adams has been for some days unwell.

3. VI:15. This morning I finished reading with George the Old Testament in the French Bible— Went to Church and heard Dr Nicholas. He read as well as Mr Carr— His text was from VI. Matthew 33. [“]But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you”— The Sermon was good, and well written; but the delivery inanimate. It was communion day; but I did not stay to the part of the Service that followed the Sermon— Mrs Adams rode to Long Ditton near Kingston, to deliver a Letter to Miss Porter, from her brother, Sir Robert— Mr Von Harten paid me a visit— He lives at Drayton Green. He has a Plantation and a Partner, at the Havanna— After dinner we took an hours walk, but the days have become so short that we must henceforth give up that practice. I lost much of the day; but wrote principally in the Evening, upon Subjects which weigh heavily upon my mind.

4. VI— Employed the day in writing to my brother, and in copying Papers to be sent by Mr M’Murtrie: I intended to have enclosed the papers to my brother, but after finishing my Letter, I concluded to take the papers to Mr M’Murtrie, and request him to make the transfer upon his arrival at Philadelphia. George rode out this morning and afterwards walked with me to Kew, over the Bridge. On our return within three minutes of home we were overtaken by a heavy shower, and were wet through. I wrote again the whole Evening— A Letter to Lord Castlereagh, and part of one to the Secretary of State— Began the reading with George of the French New Testament, comparing it with the Greek Testament.

5. VI:15. Finished my Letter to the Secretary of State; and went into London— First to the Coachmaker’s Messer and Page. The Carriage was not there which I was to have seen, but they said it would be there next Friday.— Thence I went to the glass shop, and next to Key and Jameson’s, with whom I settled for the Curricle— I then went to the New Hummums, Covent-Garden to see Mr M’Murtrie; but he was not at his lodgings— I went to Charles Street— Had a Copy made by Mr Grubb of the Letter to Lord Castlereagh to send to the Secretary of State— Then made up the Packets for him and took them again to Mr M’Murtrie’s lodgings— They had told me he would probably be there at 5 O’Clock— But he had not come in— I went back again to Charles Street, gave the packets to Mr Grubb, requesting him to call and
and give them to Mr M’Murtrie early to-morrow Morning. And to request him to take the Certificate of Stock, and the Letter of Attorney, and to make the transfer, on his arrival at Philadelphia— On returning home I stopped a third time, at the New Hummums; but Mr M’Murtrie was still not there— While I was at Charles Street, two persons came for Passports— A Mr Smith, to go to France, and a Mr Jones to go to Liverpool, and the United States— Mr Carroll the man to whom I have twice lent money to enable him to return to America came to ask a third loan, stating that he had again lost his passage— I told him that although this third application must appear suspicious from a man who was a total Stranger to me, I would yet lend him ten pounds more, if he would bring me a certificate from the Captain of the Vessel in which he now said he was going, that he had engaged his passage— A Sailor came also, with a list of the names of twenty others, to ask for the means of returning to America, and to complain of Mr Beasley, to whom however I was obliged to refer them back— It was seven O’Clock in the Evening when I got home to dinner.

6. VI:15. Mrs Adams and George went into London this Morning, to look at some Carriages, and after their return George walked with me to Brentford, and on the Windsor road— I wrote a Letter to Mr Sumter at Rio Janeiro, in answer to all those received from him within the last year— I received a letter from Mr Grubb— Mr M’Murtrie has my despatches, the Certificate of Stock and the Letter of Attorney; and has agreed to make the Transfer— He goes in the Mail to-morrow Evening for Liverpool— Also a Letter from Mr Murray at Liverpool requesting a Passport, as bearer of despatches; and one from Mr Smith the dealer in horses, which I answered. In the Evening I only read a few pages of Morgan’s Memoirs of the Life of Dr Price— And I have run three days in arrear of this journal.— Evening [symbols]

7. VI:15. After writing this morning a Letter to Mr Jackson at Paris, I went into London, and first called upon the Comte de La Chátre, the French Ambassador, to enquire whether he had received the packet which Mr Sumter had sent me for him. He said he had and that the enclosures for the king’s Ministers has already been forwarded to Paris— I told him that the care of it had been very particularly recommended to me, as it came from the Count de Gestas, whose prior despatches I understood had failed of reaching the king’s Ministers— And I had been requested by the American Minister at Rio Janeiro, who had forwarded the packet to say that he had been a witness to the zeal and activity, with which the Count de Gestas had served the king’s interests there. The Count said that this testimonial gave him great pleasure— That it had happened that the Count de Gestas was the only one, of all the diplomatic agents whom the king had employed, before his restoration; who had not after that event, been confirmed, in the same office; but it was only a mal-entendu, which he hoped would be repaired— He said that he himself had been the king’s Minister here, ever since the Ministry of Mr Fox— He was the most antient member of the Corps Diplomatique here. Though great part of the time without acknowledged public character— I asked him whether he expected Mr de Rayneval soon back. He said, perhaps next week— He had expected him sooner, but he would not come until the arrangements are terminated. He said the Elections for the Representative Chamber were generally very good; and he entertained great hopes from their meeting which was to be about the 20th. I said there had been some talk of changes in the Ministry— He said he did not think that probable— Perhaps Fouché might retire— It was much (c’est beaucoup) that he was appointed to the place he now holds— After a little further conversation upon indifferent topics, I left the Count, and went to the Chevalier de Freire’s, the Portuguese Minister— He was not at home— I left with his Secretary, my Letter to Mr Sumter with a request that he would forward it— He told me that it would be too late for this Months packet; the despatches to go by it having been made up and sent off to Falmouth, last Night. But my letter would be sent by an occasional merchant vessel, or by the Packet of next Month.— After calling at Key and Jameson the Coachmakers, I paid a visit to Mr Maclure who was not at home, and to Dr Bollmann whom I found. He is a man of very singular character and Genius— Full of intrigue, of Projects, and of information— Ardent, meditative, a mixture of calculation and Romance, which enters much into the composition of the Germans of the present age—flattering aukwardly. Vain to an incredible excess— A man who might be made in the highest degree useful, but that his flightiness of mind, and equivocal principle did not render him still more dangerous. I had Conversation with him upon various points which I can scarcely now commit to paper— But the gravity with which he exhorted me to study his writings upon finance in the American Review diverted me much— He appears to have a wish to be appointed American Agent at the Court of Vienna. I went from him to the Office in Charles Street, where I found Mr Grubb, very unwell— He had been all the morning in bed— Mr M’Murtrie had already been there and taken
his Passports— I made out the Passport as bearer of despatches, for Mr Murray, and took it with the Packet I had made up for the Secretary of State, to the New Hummums— Mr M’Murtrie was gone— He had left the house in a Hackney Coach the moment before I got there— The waiter shewed me the Coach, which I followed and overtook near Temple-Bar— I gave Mr M’Murtrie the packet and the Letter— He told me he had the Certificate of Stock, and Letter of Attorney, and would make the transfer. I returned to Charles Street— Mr Grubb was gone— Mr George Loyall had left a Letter of Recommendation to me from Mr Thomas Newton of Norfolk, and a packet of Despatches from the Secretary of State— Duplicates of those last received— I came home at a quarter past six— In the Evening I opened the Trunk received from Mr Jackson at Paris, and found the Certificates of Stock all there.

8. V:30. Wrote this morning to Messrs: Meulemeester’s and Co: at Ghent, a third letter concerning the trunks that I left there, about the fate of which I begin to be much concerned— Immediately afterwards, Valentine Butterfield, the Sailor who had been the other day at the Office, came with another Seaman, a Black Man— They had a letter, signed by five Masters of American Vessels, at the Port of London, offering to take home as many as they can of the destitute American Seamen; passage free; if they could be suitably found in Provisions, for the passage,—I received also a Letter from one of the same Captains, asking for Bedding and Cloaths for a Man, sent by Mr Beasley, on board his Vessel— I answered both the Letters and also wrote to Mr Beasley, recommending to him to accept the offer of the Captains, and to endeavour to prevail on the Masters of all the other American vessels in the Port to concur in it. These Letters which I sent by the two Seamen, employed me until breakfast time— And after journalizing for yesterday, I took a ride with Mrs Adams in the Curricle to Harrow on the Hill—about eight miles— We returned between 5 and 6. O’Clock, and I had barely time to get through the Morning reading with George before dinner— After dinner I walked with him to Brentford, and after returning wrote part of a Letter to Mr Hall, at Boston—

9. V:45. I could not finish my Letter this morning, although it was near two O’Clock, when I left home to go in to London. Having received no Letters, yesterday or this morning from Mr Grubb, I was apprehensive that his illness had continued, and that he had been unable to attend at the office— I went first to the Coachmaker’s in Margaret Street, Messer and Page, and thence to Key and Jameson’s Wardour-Street— At each of those places there was a Landau for sale, and I was to fix my choice between them. After seeing them both, I went to the Office in Charles Street, where I found Mr Grubb, who has recovered from his complaint— Mr Seth Storer was with him a brother of Mr Woodbury Storer of Portland, who is to embark next week for Boston. He offered to take Letters or despatches for me and told me a long Story of his own commercial concerns— His claims upon the Government of Naples for Murat’s depredations and his lawsuit with a commercial house here— There were also half a dozen Letters— One from Mr Murray at Liverpool, brought by a Mr Aborn— One from Smith the Horse-dealer, threatening me with a Sollicitor.— One from Mr Harris at St Petersburg, concerning the Privilege to Mr Fulton, and two from Mr A. H. Everett, one by the Post from the Hague, and the other a Letter of Recommendation, written in June 1813. and brought by a Mr Coffin— While I was at the Office a Letter was brought in from Mr Morier, in answer to one of the Subjects upon which I wrote to him last week— Shortly after five I left the Office; called at Silvester’s in the Strand; where I took my Seal; then at Key and Jameson’s with whom I could not agree for their Landau; and then at Messer and Page’s where I took their’s upon trial until Monday Morning— I came home in it, leaving my Curricle with them— It was half past seven, when I reached home— I found John and Charles at home from school— Mr Barberi finishes this day, giving them & George fencing Lessons.

10. VI:30. We all went to Church this morning— The service was performed and the Sermon preached by Mr Lewis— The Sermon, from Psalm XIX.14. “Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart, be acceptable in the sight, O Lord, my strength, and my redeemer,” was much better than any one that I had heard from the same person before— It was an exposition of the whole of that admirable Psalm from which the text was taken—a very feeble one indeed, but superior to any thing that I should have expected from the Preacher— After Church, Mrs Adams and the Children rode to Richmond— I began a Letter to my Mother, and walked with George an hour before dinner— Mr Beasley came out and dined with us— John was taken so unwell while we were at dinner that we could not send him back this Evening to school— Charles was also unwell and kept at home.

11. VI:15. John and Charles were this day much recovered; but it was concluded not to send them to school until to-morrow morning— The Carpenters came, and began to make the changes in my Cabinet—opening two of the side windows and closing in their stead, two of those at the end— They make it for the time very inconvenient to read or write in my chamber— I finished however my Letter to my Mother— Mr West the mechanic who lodges at Mr Grubb’s came out to consult with me about his projects for Patents. He has obtained or is applying for four or five here— One for threshing corn—another for pounding rice— A third for a new Carriage
Spring, and others which he endeavoured to explain to me, without much success. He also wishes to take out a number of useful patent inventions from this Country, to take out Patents for them in the United States—for which purpose he wishes an alteration in the Patent Law, of the United States— He says there is a late Act of Parliament here, by virtue of which foreigners can take out Patents. I asked him to procure a copy of that Act of Parliament and of any other useful information upon the subject; and promised to write concerning it to America— I walked with George an hour and a half before dinner; and wrote again in the Evening.

12. VI:30. A short despatch to the Secretary of State— John and Charles returned to school, and I went into London with George. We had not been more than five minutes on the road, when we met Mr Sanders the black man, with Mr Bryden, a young Gentleman whom he had brought out as an acquaintance for George— Sanders said he expected to go for France on Thursday, and wished me to be useful to him— He was desirous of having some conversation with me— I asked him and Mr Bryden, to stay and dine with us, and promised to be at home at six O’Clock— We went to the Office in Charles Street, where I found with Mr Grubb, a Mran American, waiting for a Passport. There were afterwards three or four others who also applied for, and obtained Passports— The Clerk of Smith the Horse dealer came again to demand payment of his account— I answered him in anger—complained of imposition—asked him if he knew the situation I stood in here, when he threatened me with a solicitor, and perceiving that in his talk, he was endeavouring to entrap me into some concession of which he might take advantage I told him I saw his drift, and should abide only by what I had written— I would pay him no more— In all this, I spoke unadvisedly with my lips, because, although I deliberately think it a scandalous attempt to impose upon me, yet it is unworthy of me for such a trifle to suffer myself to be put out of temper— Mr Carroll came with a Certificate from Captain Joshua Knight, Master of the Ship John and Adam, that he should have a passage to New-York in that vessel, and I lent him ten pounds more upon his Bill on Alexander Orrok. I gave him also the despatches for the Secretary of State, and the packets for Boston, to be delivered to Mr Storer at the New-England Coffee-House. Mr Loyall came, and brought me a few American Newspapers, and Mr Rawle for a Passport to go to France. I wrote a Note to Lord Bathurst requesting an interview with him— He was at Putney and will have my note to-morrow. A Mr: Smith an Englishman came to ask me some questions about an Estate to which he supposes himself to be entitled, in Florida. I was so much engaged that he determined to call again. A French Lady, who called herself Fleury, came to enquire after Mr Gallatin and Mr Storrow, whom she said she and her mother had known at Ghent; and Mr Gallatin at Princess Dolgorouki’s at St Petersburg— They wished to write to those Gentlemen, and they wished also to go to America— I thought but was not sure that it was Madame Julien the actress— I had ordered the Carriage at four O’Clock, and until past that hour the Office was not a moment without company.— We hastened home, and found that Mr Sanders and Mr Bryden had concluded, not to dine with us this day, but to come again on Thursday.— Instead of writing in the Evening, I read over for the second time the Exposition of the causes, and character of the War, which Cobbett has contrived to get into extensive circulation here.

13. VI:45. Sent the Coachman into London this Morning for the Curricle, and to call at the Office for any Letters that might be there for me— There were none— The Carpenters are still at work in my Cabinet, and interrupt me in my occupations— I only wrote Two or three short Letters— Went with Mrs Adams and paid visits to Coll. and Mrs. and Miss Clitherow. They were gone to London, and we left Cards— Walk with George before dinner to the Brentford Fair— And after dinner again with Mrs Adams and George— We saw one of the Shows, a double jointed ox, between two and three feet high, a sheep with five legs, an Armadillo, a Jackall and a Baboon.— We also stopp’d and saw several people looking through a magic lanthorn, the Showman of which announced that it was a view of the burning of the City of Washington; by General Ross— He said there was not a house in that City but what was in flames. And his next Show was the Battle of Waterloo, where he said the British army had lost thirteen thousand men, killed and wounded— While we were listening to him in the crowd, I felt a hand making a plunge at my Coat pocket, and was in time to prevent its getting in— This was another kind of British hostility from which it was expedient to remove, and we returned home— The Fair is confined within the limits of the market square, and is frequented only by children and the rabble. It continues three days— After returning home I played Back-gammon with George about half an hour.— The warmth of the weather, and the uncomfortable situation of my chamber prevented me from writing. It was I think the warmest day there has been this Summer— The Season has been uncommonly dry, and the last ten days there has been no rain. [symbols]

14. VI— This morning was occupied in reading over the Letters which I have received from my father and the enclosures in them. The Carpenters finished their work in my Cabinet, where they have been nearly a week employed in opening two side windows, and closing two at the end. Mr Sanders and Mr Bryden came out before I left home— A young Frenchman named Sabatier also came to ask me for Letters of Recommendation to America— He is a carver and engraver, and wishes to go and settle in that Country. I went into London, and as I had anticipated found a Note from Lord Bathurst, appointing two O’Clock this day to see me at Downing-Street— It was then just two, and I went immediately to his Office, and had an interview with him of about an hour— I said that having lately received despatches from the American Secretary of State respecting several objects of some importance to the relations between the two Countries, my first object in asking to see him had been to enquire whether he had received from Mr Baker a Communication of the Correspondence between Mr Monroe and him, relative to the surrender of Michillimakinac, to the proceedings of Coll: Nicolls in the Southern part of the United States; and to the warning given by the Captain of a British armed vessel, to certain American fishing vessels to withdraw from the fishing grounds to the distance of twenty leagues from the Coast— He said that he had received all these papers from Mr Baker about four days ago, that an answer with regard to the warning of the fishing vessels had immediately been sent; but on the other subjects there had not been time to examine the papers and prepare the answers— I asked him if he could without inconvenience state the substance of the answer that had been sent— He said, certainly— It had been that as on the one hand Great-Britain could not permit the vessels of the United States to fish within the Creeks, and close upon the shores of the British territories, so on the other hand it was by no means her intention to interrupt them in fishing any where in the open sea, or without the territorial jurisdiction—a marine league from the shore— And therefore that the warning given in the place stated in the case referred to was unauthorised. I said that the particular act being disavowed, I trusted the British Government before adopting any final determination upon the Subject, would estimate in candour and in the Spirit of amity which my own Government was anxious to have prevailing in our relations with this Country, the Considerations which I was instructed to present in support of the right of the People of the United States to fish on the whole Coast of North-America, which they have uniformly enjoyed from the first settlement of the Country. That I should in the course of a few days address a Letter to him on the Subject. He said that they would give due attention to the Letter that I should send him, but that Great-Britain had explicitly manifested her intention upon the Subject— That there was a great deal of feeling on it in this Country, as I doubtless knew, and their own fishermen considered it as an excessive hardship to be supplanted by American fishermen even upon the very shores of the British dominions— I said that those whose sensibilities had been thus excited, had probably not considered the question of right, in the point of view in which it had been regarded by us. That the question of right had not been discussed at the negotiation of Ghent— That the British Plenipotentiaries had given a notice that the British Government would not hereafter allow the People of the United States to fish and cure and dry fish within the exclusive British territorial Jurisdiction in America, without an equivalent. That the American Plenipotentiaries had given notice in return, that the American Government considered all the rights to the fisheries on the whole Coast of North America, as sufficiently secured by their enjoyment of them from the settlement of the Country by them, and by the recognition of it in the Treaty of Peace of 1783. That they did not think any new stipulation necessary for a further confirmation of the right— No part of which did they consider as having been forfeited by the War— It was perfectly obvious that the Treaty of Peace of 1783 was not one of those ordinary Treaties which by the usages of Nations were considered as annulled by a subsequent war between the same parties. It was a Treaty of partition between two parts of one Nation agreeing thenceforth to be separated into two distinct Sovereignties— The Conditions upon which this was done constituted essentially the Independence of the United States, and the preservation of all the fishing rights which they had always enjoyed, over the whole Coast of North America, was among the most important of them— This was no concession no grant on the part of Great-Britain which could be annulled by a War— There had been in the same Treaty of 1783. a right recognized in British subjects to navigate the Mississippi— This right the British Plenipotentiaries at Ghent had considered a just claim of Great-Britain, notwithstanding the war that had intervened— The American Plenipotentiaries, to remove all future discussion upon both points had offered to agree to an article expressly confirming both the rights— In declining this an Offer had been made on the part of Great-Britain, stipulating to negotiate in future for the renewal of both rights, for an equivalent. This was declined by the American Plenipotentiaries because its only effect would have been an implied admission, that both the rights were annulled— There was therefore no Article concerning them in the Treaty, and the question as to the right was not discussed. I now stated the ground upon which the Government of the United States considered the right as subsisting and unimpaired— It would be for the British Government ultimately to determine how far this reasoning was to be admitted as correct.
There were also considerations of policy and expediency to which I hoped the British Government would give suitable attention before they came to a final decision upon this point— I thought it my duty to suggest them; that they might not be overlooked— The subject was viewed by my Countrymen as highly important, and I was profoundly anxious to omit nothing which might possibly have an influence to promote friendly sentiments between the two Nations, or to guard against the excitement of others.— These fisheries afforded the means of subsistence to multitudes of people, who were destitute of any other— They also afforded the means of remittance to G. Britain, in payment for articles of her manufacture exported to America— It was well understood to be the policy of Great-Britain that no unnecessary encouragement or stimulus should be given to manufactures in the United States, which would diminish the importations from those of Great-Britain— But by depriving the fishermen of the United States of this source of subsistence, the result must be to throw them back upon the Country, and drive them to the resort of manufacturing for themselves—while on the other hand, it would cut off the means of making remittances in payment for the manufactures of Great-Britain— I might add that the people in America whose interests would be immediately and severely affected by this exclusion, were in the part of the Country which had always manifested of late years most friendly dispositions towards Great-Britain— This might perhaps be less proper for me to suggest than for a British Cabinet to consider— To me the interests of all my Countrymen, in every part of the United States was the same. I could know no distinction between them. But upon a point where I was contending for what we conceived a strict right, I thought it best to urge every consideration which might influence the other party to avoid a collision upon it— I would even urge considerations of humanity— I would say that fisheries, the nature of which was to multiply the means of subsistence to mankind, were usually considered by civilized Nations as under a sort of special Sanction— It was a common practice to leave them uninterrupted even in time of war— He knew for instance that the Dutch had been for centuries in the practice of fishing upon the Coasts of this Island, and that they were not interrupted in this occupation even in ordinary times of war— It was to be inferred from this that to interrupt a fishery which had been enjoyed for ages was itself an indication of more than ordinary animosity— He said that no such disposition was entertained by the British Government— That to shew the liberality which they had determined to exercise in this case he would assure me that the Instructions which he had given to the Officers on that Station had been, not even to interrupt the American fishermen, who might have proceeded to those Coasts within the British Jurisdiction, for the present year—to allow them to complete their fares, but to give them notice, that this privilege could be no longer allowed by Great-Britain, and that they must not return the next year— It was not so much the fishing, as the drying and curing on the shores that had been followed with bad consequences— It happened that our fishermen by their proximity, could get to the fishing Stations sooner in the Season than the British, who were obliged to go from Europe, and who upon arriving there found all the fishing places, and drying and curing places preoccupied— This had often given rise to disputes and quarrels between them, which in some instances had proceeded even to blows— It had even disturbed the Peace among the inhabitants on the shores; and for several years before the war, the complaints to this Government had been so great and so frequent that it had been impossible not to pay regard to them— I said that I had not heard of any such complaints before—but that as to the disputes arising from the competition of the fishermen, they could surely be easily made a subject of regulation, by the Government, and as to the Peace of the Inhabitants there could be no difficulty in securing that; as the liberty enjoyed by the American fishermen, was in all settled and inhabited places, expressly subjected to the consent of the inhabitants, and by agreement with them— I then adverted to the other topics—Michillimakinac—Bois Blan—and Coll. Nicolls— I asked him if he had any account of the delivery of the Post— He said he had no doubt whatever; but that it had been long since delivered up— But he had no late despatches from the Canadian Government— Some delay had occurred by the change of the Governor General; but Sir George Prevost’s leaving Quebec to come to Europe, and consequently by General Drummond’s coming from upper Canada to Quebec— As to the indisposition manifested by the Indians to accept the Peace offered by the United States, he regretted it very much— It had been the sincere wish and intention of the British Government that the Peace with the Indians should immediately follow that agreed to by this Country, the British Officers there had been formally instructed to make known to them the Peace which had been concluded, and to advise them to take the benefit of it— As to Coll: Nicolls I said that the American Government had been peculiarly concerned at the proceedings of that Officer, because they appeared marked with unequivocal characters of hostility— Why, said Lord Bathurst to tell you the truth, Coll: Nicolls, is I believe a man of activity and Spirit, but a very wild fellow— He did make and send over to me a Treaty Offensive and defensive with the Indians, and he is now come over here and has brought over some of those Indians
I sent for answer that he had no authority whatever to make a Treaty offensive and defensive with the Indians, and that this Government would make no such Treaty. I have sent him word that I could not see him upon any such project— The Indians are here in great distress indeed; but we shall only furnish them with the means of returning home, and advise them, to make their terms with the United States as well as they can— Perceiving that I had noticed his declaration that he had declined seeing Coll. Nicolls, he said that perhaps he should see him upon the general subject of his transactions but that he had declined seeing him in regard to his Treaty with the Indians— I then observed that Mr Monroe had also sent me his Letter to Mr Baker concerning the Island of Bois Blanc. He said, it seemed merely a question of fact; whether the Island had been in the possession of the British at the Commencement of the late War, or not— He did not know how that was, but he thought it could not be difficult to ascertain; and it was altogether of very little importance. I then asked him if he could inform me, when Mr Bagot would probably embark for the United States— He laughed and said he believed he must refer me to the man midwife— They had expected Mrs Bagot would be confined about this time, and to be ready to go early in October— I said that I had asked the question now, because by a late Letter from Mr Baker to the American Secretary of State, it appeared that his powers in relation to the execution of the Treaty of Peace were less extensive than the Government of the United States had understood they were; which circumstance had made me more solicitous for the departure of Mr Bagot— He said there would be no delay that could possibly be avoided.— After this conference I went to the engraver Silvester’s in the Strand.— Left the Seal, for an alteration.— As I was returning to Charles Street, I met the Sardinian Minister, Count St: Martin d’Aglie, in the Street— He says that the Treaty of Peace with France is signed— That France will retain her boundaries of 1789. without dismemberment only restoring to his king, what had been taken from him by the Treaty of Paris of May 1814— He says that there is a political fanaticism prevailing in Germany of which an association calling themselves friends of virtue has been the consequence— They were the great declaimers for the dismemberment of France; but it was not sufficient to desire a thing; it must also be considered what was practicable— I left Charles Street, about half past four, and reached home at six. Mr Sanders and Mr Bryden dined with us; and our Sons John and Charles were at home for a half holiday from school— They returned in the Evening.

15. VI:15. I had the Carpenters again at work in my writing room, great part of the morning.— We all went and dined with Mr William Vaughan and his Sisters,—one of whom however was unwell and did not appear— The company were Admiral Sir Benjamin Hallowell and his Lady, Mr & Mrs Dickason, Mr and Mrs Amory, and Mr Coffin, and Mr Vaughan’s nephew Petty— Admiral Hallowell resides at Ealing, in our neighbourhood— He is a brother of Mr Ward Boylston’s. He appears to be dissatisfied with the reduction of the Navy, though he is himself retained in service upon the Peace Establishment, and is to command upon the Station at Cork— He expects to go in eight or ten days. Mr Dickason gave me a copy of a Letter to Mr Erving, requesting him to put in a claim upon the Spanish Government for an American Vessel taken by an English Cruizer, within the Spanish Jurisdiction, and carried to Gibraltar. Mr Dickason desired me to make application upon the Subject to the Spanish Ambassador here, and promised to furnish me the Papers— We came home in the Evening about 11. O’Clock.

16. VI:30. This morning I received a notification that the Trunks which I have been so long expecting from Ostend had arrived; in consequence of which I went with Mrs Adams into London— We paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Amory, but did not find them at home. We stopp’d at Mrs Copley’s door, but concluded it was too soon to pay her a visit— Mr Copley died last Saturday. We went to Charles Street, and I immediately called upon Mr Morier, the Under Secretary of State in Downing Street. I found on enquiry there that the order from the Treasury to the Custom-House for the landing of my Trunks arrived from Ostend had been sent on the 20th: of July, at the time when I applied to Mr Hamilton for it— Mr Morier said I had only to direct application to be made at the Custom-house to Mr M’Lean, and the trunks would be delivered— I asked Mr Morier whether he had received from me a list of Negroes— He said he had— And then said, Lord Bathurst had explained to me the circumstances respecting Coll: Nicolls— I said yes— I asked him whether they were likely soon to settle their affairs in France— He said they had made considerable progress, and it must be drawing to a conclusion. There were so many parties, that some shades of difference in opinion had arisen among them, as to what was best to be done; but they would probably be all soon smoothed down— I asked him whether he could tell me when Mr Bagot would probably embark for America; Mrs Bagot having now got a daughter— He could not tell; but said I should have notice in ample time to write by him— On returning to the office I gave Mr Grubb the Bill of lading, and Letter of Notification, requesting him to see to the landing of the trunks and sending them out
to us at Ealing on Monday, if it could be. After a walk with Mrs Adams, we returned home— We walked from Gunnersbury House; nearly two Miles, and were sprinkled with rain. There was a very heavy shower this morning at our house, but it did not extend a mile from it, and great part of the way to and from London, we were much annoyed by the dust.— In the Evening I began a Letter to the Secretary of State.

17. VI:15. Attended Church both at the Morning and Afternoon Service— Mr Carr preached in the morning— His text from XI Matthew 30. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light— The afternoon preacher was a stranger— His sermon was from V. Job. 5. and 6. Although affliction cometh not forth of the dust, neither doth trouble spring out of the ground; yet man is born unto trouble as the sparks fly upward— Both dull discourses. I mistook the hour when the second service begins and was half an hour too late— The reading of prayers was finished before I went in— After the morning service I rode round and returned Mr Von Harten’s visit, but he was not at home— As I was returning from the second Service, I met Major Morison and Mr Copland, on horse-back, who had just called to pay a visit at my house— I found Mr Joy there— We returned however to London to dinner— In the leisure of the day and Evening, I continued writing to the Secretary of State—particularly, two hours after dinner.

18. VI.— I finished my letter to the Secretary of State— Then brought up this Journal, and in the Evening began a Letter to my father. But I cannot possibly keep pace with my intentions— George went into London to the circulating Library and brought home some books— I took a solitary walk an hour before dinner— Received two Letters from Mr Grubb, respecting the Trunks from Ostend, which are not likely to be landed for three or four days—also a Letter from Spain, enclosing one for Mr Erving. It came with a packet too large to be forwarded by the Post.

19. VI:15. I could not this morning finish my Letter to my father, having received before breakfast an enclosure from Mr Grubb, with several Letters— There was one from Mr Wortham, the Solicitor of Mr Smith the horse dealer; demanding payment again of his bill— One from Dr Kirkland, President of Harvard University, recommending Mr William Cranch Bond, and enclosing a Letter of Recommendation of him to Mr Pond, the Astronomer Royal.— Mr Bond has come to obtain information for the construction of an Observatory at Cambridge, and to bespeak Instruments for it— He left the Letters yesterday at the Office— I went with Mrs Adams and George into London— We called first at the circulating Library, where I wanted to procure Anderson’s History of Commerce— I could get only the first volume, and that not complete— I now feel very severely the want of a Library— We then went to see Mr West’s Pictures that are exhibited in Pall-Mall— There are two large ones—Christ healing the Sick, and Christ rejected— Both very fine pictures, but not satisfying me— There is not idealism enough in West’s Pictures. There is not beauty enough in his female faces, and not ease and grace enough in any of his figures— There are several smaller Pictures, and sketches, less admirable than the great pictures. We went to the Office in Charles Street— I found there a Mr Waters, with documents for a claim of two or three Millions of dollars, of a Canadian named Casaux, against the United States for services and expenditures, during the War of American Independence— Mr Waters prevailed upon me to take these papers, and to promise to look over them, and see him again about them on Saturday— There was also a Mr King, from Charleston South-Carolina, who brought me Letters of Recommendation, from Mr Stephen Elliott, and Mr William Crafts— Mr Elliott is President of a Literary and Philosophical Society, lately formed at Charleston, and Mr King comes upon pursuits connected with the Society— I promised to see him again at the Office on Thursday. Mr Bond came also, and after some conversation with him I agreed to go with him on Thursday to Greenwich to introduce him to Mr Pond— There was a large packet from Mr Brent the Secretary of Legation at Madrid, enclosing one for Mr Erving, with a Letter addressed to the Minister or Consul of the United States at London, requesting him to forward the Packet for Mr Erving— Another large packet from Commodore Decatur enclosing a number of Letters to be forwarded—a Letter from Decatur to me, announcing the Algerine Peace— A Letter from Mr Harris at St Petersburg, and a short Note from Mr Morier, about suits in the Admiralty Court, for Sailor’s wages. These visitors and Letters occupied me so that I had barely time to make up the Packet of Dispatches for the Secretary of State and request Mr Grubb to have it forwarded as speedily as possible, either from this Post, or under cover to Mr Maury at Liverpool— Wrote also several Cards— We returned home, and I walked with George about the last half of the way—from 1 1/2 mile beyond Acton— It was seven O’Clock when we reached home— And consequently so late when we had dined, that I had no time after dinner, to do any thing more than file the Letters and papers that I have received.

20. VI:15. Finished the Letter to my father, upon the subject which of all others now gives me the most concern, and uneasiness— Wasted this morning a portion of my time, with the prospect of a task before, which ought speedily and yet not hastily to be performed. Brought up my Journal which has a perpetual tendency to run in arrears.— Sent the Coachman into Town with the Landau, to be put in Condition. Walked with George before dinner, round by Gunnersbury house.— Wrote again in the Evening.

21. VI— After writing one or two short Letters this Morning I went into London with the Curricle. I had promised to be at Noon, at the Office in Charles Street, but it was close upon one, when I got there. I found Mr Bond there, and after having been detained an hour in making up despatches, and Letters, and by several Americans applying for Passports, I took a Hackney Coach and went with him to Greenwich. We enquired there of several persons for the royal observatory, but none of them any more than our Coachman knew any thing about it, or understood what we meant— I then enquired for the Astronomer Royal, and at last found a man who said. Oh! that’s Captain Pond. He lives at Flamstead House, and then directed the Coachman to the Park gate— When we went up to the house, we found that Mr Pond was not at home— We left the books and Letters, and after walking an hour about the Park, and Mr Pond not having returned, Mr Bond concluded to stay and lodge this Night at Greenwich and to call again upon Mr Pond in the Evening— I returned in the Hackney Coach alone to Charles Street; and after going and taking my Seal at Silvester’s, I returned home in precisely one hour from Charles Street. I got home just at seven— In the Evening I began the second draft of a Letter to Lord Bathurst upon the fisheries— The first being utterly unsatisfactory to myself.

22. VI— After the longest series of dry and beautiful weather that I ever knew in England, there was this day an appearance of change, and the prospect of an Equinoctial Storm— I was employed, though with more than sufficient intervals of relaxation, the whole day, and Evening upon the draft of my Letter to Lord Bathurst— Walked round by Gunnersbury House and through Brentford, with George before dinner— Wrote after dinner until ten, and afterwards the time slip’d away in Conversation until Midnight.

23. VI:15. I had intended to have gone this morning into London, but was deterred by the appearance of the weather, which was gloomy, and still more by the desire to prepare my Letter to Lord Bathurst, the greater part of which I copied from my draft. I feel severely the want of large Library to consult for this discussion, and I have not even the most necessary books!— John and Charles came home from school to pass the Sunday— I walked with George round through Brentford, and returned by the way of Gunnersbury house— And have now ascertained the distances with almost as much accuracy as could be done with a chain.

24. V:45. We had this day the equinoctial storm— Rain all the morning and until 4. in the afternoon when it cleared away. I finished the fair copy of my Letter to Lord Bathurst, and enclosed it to Mr Grubb, for another fair Copy to be made out for to-morrow, when I intend to go into Town— This paper has given and yet gives me great anxiety. I recurred to the only book that I have, which could give me any useful information on the subjects—La Cepede’s Natural History of Fishes—and under the Article Gade Morue, found something— Walked with George the four mile walk before dinner— John and Charles returned to school this Evening and I wrote a short Letter to the Secretary of State, and one to my brother, enclosing M. Carroll’s three drafts.

25. V:45. I went into London in the Curricle, and after stopping at the Coachmakers, where the work on the Carriage was done wrong, and must be altered, and at the boot-makers, and circulating library, I went to the office in Charles Street. It was between three and four O’Clock, and Mr Grubb had not received my Letter until between twelve and one— It was impossible for him to finish the fair copy of that for Lord Bathurst in time for me to sign it this day— He is to send it out to me therefore to-morrow; and I am to return it in the Evening, or Wednesday Morning— There was a circular note from Lord Bathurst dated on the 23d: instant, giving notice that the recent restrictions upon the departure of Aliens from this Country, being deemed no longer necessary were to cease from the date of the Note— There was also a packet from Mr T. M. Jones at Birmingham, with a Book, some of Cobbett’s Registers, and a couple of American Songs— I called upon Dr Bollmann who informed me he should go on Thursday morning, either to Falmouth to embark in the Packet, or to Liverpool, to go in the Helvetius to Philadelphia— He mentioned again his wishes to be employed in Europe, and the wish that I would recommend him— He had a late Letter from France which he read to me, and spoke again of the proposal made to the Government of the United States, through him— I called at Silvester’s and spoke of the device for a Seal; the Constellation—Lyra— In the Strand I procured, the Exposition of the Causes and character of the War—7th: Edition, and the eleventh number of the Pamphleteer. Returned to Charles Street; then to the Coachmaker’s Messer and Page, and finally home about half past seven O’Clock— After dinner I read the new Edition of Atcheson’s pamphlet, about half through.

26. V:45. The day was stormy, with so much rain that I was deprived of the exercise of walking, except about half an hour in the Garden. I wrote to Mr Maury, and then to Mr Beasley, enclosing an extract of the Letter which I lately received from Commodore Decatur, concerning the Algerine Peace— I also wrote a Letter to the President of the United States. Mr and Mrs Amory, and Messrs Coffin, Joy, King, Langdon, Loyall, Maclure, Murdoch and Williams dined with us— Mr King wishes to obtain here for the Literary and Philosophical Society of South Carolina copies of antient papers from the Colonial Office; and to get access to them by an Introduction from me— I have doubts of the propriety of my giving it to him— He has also proposals for the publication of a large historical work, by the late Dr Ramsay. He left the paper of them with me, and a letter on the subject to himself— Mr Joy left with me a Letter from his brother Benjamin to him concerning his application for an Appointment.— We had fire the first time for the Season in our drawing room.

27. V:45. The approach of winter begins to interrupt my Morning occupations and I was prevented by the cold from writing this morning before Breakfast— I concluded to go into London, principally to see Dr Bollmann, again. I went in the Curricle, and returned in the Landau— I signed and sent in the Letter to Lord Bathurst— There were several applications for Passports to go to America, nothwithstanding the notice given in Lord Bathurst’s circular Letter of the 23d. instant.— I called upon Dr Bollmann, and gave him the Letter, which I requested him to deliver, himself.— I intimated to him also, that he might perhaps find some prejudices against him at Washington; which would interfere with his present views.— He thought, they could only have arisen from his concerns with Coll. Burr; but I gave him to understand that there might be others of more recent origin; and referred him to reports of conversations held by him last Summer, and autumn— Mr Grubb promised to make up the packet of despatches, to give to Dr Bollmann this Evening, or to-morrow Morning before ten O’Clock— I received at the Office several Letters from America—one of them from my Mother, informing me that Mr & Mrs W. S. Smith, had lost their daughter, by the Measles— One from Mr Maury at Liverpool, who has a packet for me, not to be put into the Post-Office— And a large packet from Messrs: T. Dickason and Co: enclosing the papers in the case, upon which they wished me to make application to the Spanish Ambassador— I read them all as I was riding home; which I reached at 5. O’Clock— I intended not to have shewn my wife the Letter from my Mother, until to-morrow Morning; but there was a Letter to George, which also mentioned the Death of Catherine’s child, which was thus immediately disclosed to Mrs Adams— She was so much affected by it, that she could not go out as she had intended this Evening. At Seven O’Clock I went with George to Dr Nicholas’s School, and saw the performance of Terence’s Adelphi by some of the Scholars— The performances were very good. The Prologue and Epilogue were spoken twice, which made them rather tedious. Dr Nicholas allowed my Sons, John and Charles to sit with me— The dresses of the boys were all of modern fashion and some of them very elegant— The Duke of Kent’s band, attended, as the Orchestra— There were many Ladies attended and a few Gentlemen— The exhibition finished soon after ten.

28. VI:45. The morning was cold, and I employed it in reading instead of writing. At one O’Clock we all went to Dr Nicholas’s School, and heard the exhibition of English Speaking. They began with Scenes and Dialogues from Shakespear—Henry the 5th: Brutus and Cassïus—Hotspur and Owen Glendower, Othello &c— Then the Parliamentary debate in 1742. The famous altercation between Horace Walpole, and the first William Pitt. The Stage was fitted up in imitation of the House of Commons; with the Speaker in his Chair and the two Clerks at the Table, all in their wigs and gowns, and part of the school-boys on the benches to form the house. The speaking was all very good— The best Speaker was a young man named Fletcher, who spoke the Prologue to the Play last Evening, and performed the part of Demea— He was Mr Pitt in the debate, and concluded the debate by speaking Pope’s Ruling Passion. It lasted about two hours, and was more crowded with company than last Evening.— The Duke of Kent was there— And still, many more ladies than Gentlemen. John and Charles come home with us, and the Doctor allows them for Michaelmas, Holidays until Sunday Evening— I walked with George the four Mile walk, and in the Evening Mrs Adams went with all the boys to see the Play performed again— This was the last of the three Evenings— I passed it at home reading and writing.

29. VI— Michaelmas day— Something of a Holiday in England, though I believe it has ceased to be celebrated even in the Catholic Countries— It was a stormy and rainy day, so that I barely found time to walk about an hour before dinner with George— I employed the day chiefly in writing, but lost much of the time— Received a Note from Mr Grubb with notice that the trunks from Ostend have at length reached Charles Street, and that he has received the packet from Mr Maury at Liverpool, which he had been directed not
to put into the Post-Office. I sent the Coachman to town to bring them out, but Mr Grubb was gone before he reached the Office. There was a German, named Leyser, who came out, and wanted assistance to go to America, where he wishes to settle— His Country having been heretofore part of France, and now having fallen to Prussia.

30. VI. Mrs Adams, and the boys, John and Charles went with me into London, and we paid first a visit to Mr: and Mrs Perkins. The Lady only was at home. They propose to go very shortly to France— When we came to the Office at Charles Street we found there a Mr Carver, who had been twice to ask my assistance to pay his debts and go to America. He was now come a third time and with a new Story. I told him I could not lend him money, and I thought the Gentlemen at whose instance he said he had declined the invitation of the Emperor of Russia, and subsequent advantageous engagement to go to the East-Indies, ought to supply him, with what he needed— Mr Cruger called and took leave; going to France; and Mr King, going to Liverpool to return to America— He asked my further advice for his application in behalf of the Literary and Philosophical Society of South-Carolina, to obtain Copies of old documents from the Office of the Colonial Department, and for the projected Publication of Dr Ramsay’s posthumous works. I declined soliciting Mr Goulburn for the Papers, under the expectation that they would be refused, and even that some umbrage might be taken at my making the request. On public considerations I thought it best not to incur the hazard of exciting suspicion or giving offence at that office. With regard to the publication of Dr: Ramsay’s works, he had prepared a History of America, to form two Volumes octavo— And an Abridgment of Universal History, to form ten or twelve— I thought the publication of the first might be successful, but that the other would be too voluminous, and expensive. Mr King was of the same opinion— He had found that to obtain a copy right here, it would be necessary to have the book printed, but not published in America, and to deposit fifteen copies of it at Stationers Hall. After which a bargain for the copy-right might be made with a Bookseller. He said that Dr Ramsay’s Executor was a Grandson of Coll: Haynes, and that Dr: Ramsay’s widow, a daughter of President Laurens, with a large family of Children had been left in distressed and indigent Circumstances— The Doctor having been of a speculative turn, and unfortunate in his speculations, at the latter period of his life— I went with the two boys to Mr Maclure’s lodgings, and left there, the letter for my Mother— It was between 7 and 8 in the Evening when we got home.
Day. Without Variation since the last Month—
